channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Biden’s New Vaccine Mandate Could Affect 80 Million US Workers
item.description: Biden announced yesterday that all businesses with 101+ workers will need to mandate vaccines or administer weekly tests for employees, potentially affecting 80 million US workers. And Biden’s not just taking aim at the private sector—all federal workers will need to get vaccinated within 75 days or face losing their jobs.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: It's Electric: The Stock Market After 9/11
item.description: The attacks on NYC’s World Trade Center struck the US financial industry’s central nervous system, where only blocks away from the towers thousands of traders bought and sold stocks at the New York Stock Exchange. For the final installment in the series, we’re going back to our roots and discussing 9/11’s impact on the stock market. Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 10
item.description: Quote: “I want a labor market so tight that you don’t even have to cover up your tattoos to get a job. (Aeon)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Launches Smart Glasses With Ray-Ban
item.description: With the glasses, you can... For these smart glasses to gain traction, Facebook will have to convince consumers that they’re not unwitting characters in an episode of Black Mirror.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: JPMorgan Says It will to Buy Restaurant-Discovery Service the Infatuation
item.description: In 2019, American Express acquired Resy, the restaurant reservation platform, in a bid to hold onto its card members amid fierce competition from other credit-card issuers.  Bottom line: While this type of deal is rare, it isn’t without precedent.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Lululemon Reports Better Than Expected Earnings
item.description: And recent patents show Lulu could be exploring wellness products that use biometric monitoring technology. Lululemon has already integrated Mirror, the at-home fitness company it bought last year, into 150 of its brick-and-mortar stores. Double down on becoming a "tech" company.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 9
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: In the Afghan countryside, the endless killing of civilians turned women against the occupiers who claimed to be helping them.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Examining the Pop Culture Legacy of the September 11 Attacks
item.description: Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later. Before September 11, 2001, movies like Independence Day and Armageddon gleefully depicted the annihilation of American cities. — NF How long will it be before a director pitches a pandemic film?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Energy Department Report Says Solar Could Power Almost Half of US Electricity by 2050
item.description: The US Energy Department said that solar energy could power 44% of the country’s electricity by 2050, up from 3% currently, in a major report released yesterday.  Big picture: US solar installations grew a record 43% from 2019 to 2020, which means that 20% of the country’s entire solar capacity was installed last year alone.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The SEC Threatens to Sue Coinbase
item.description: Coinbase contends that Lend doesn’t involve securities and called that assumption “strange.” In this case, the SEC says they’ll sue Coinbase if and when it launches Lend. That’s how Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong described the SEC’s latest crypto crackdown. In a blog post and a nowadays-mandatory Twitter thread, Coinbase executives said they don’t understand what grounds the SEC is suing them on, and that the SEC has refused to loop them in.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Home, Sweet Futuristic, Home: The Rise of High-Tech Consumer Products
item.description: ) But what’s really important to keep in mind is that whether it’s tech that cleans or tech that drives you to work—it’s all here to make our lives easier. Ultrasonic recognition tech gives you complete control. In terms of recognition of obstacles in the home, for example, AI allows machines to take in complex data and make sense of it on the fly. Compared to just camera-based navigation, LiDAR allows for a level of precision that can help your tech move like it’s actually, truly smart. And while some people are still standing on street corners wondering why they can’t hail a flying taxi, we’re here to talk about the futuristic tech that can be in your home today.  And while this tech can tell a product where they are, it can also tell it where not to go.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Lululemon Reports Better Than Expected Earnings
item.description: what do you even do when you hit your revenue goals two years ahead of schedule? Last year, Lululemon bought at-home fitness company Mirror in hopes to be your ultimate workout buddy. Double down on becoming a tech company.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Energy Department Report Says Solar Could Power Almost Half of US Electricity by 2050
item.description: The US Energy Department said that solar energy could power 44% of the country’s electricity by 2050, up from 3% currently, in a major report released yesterday. Another barrier: How dependent the US solar industry is on China.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The SEC Threatens to Sue Coinbase
item.description: But Coinbase says Lend doesn’t involve securities and called that assumption “strange.” In this case, the SEC says they’ll sue Coinbase if and when it launches Lend. Lend would let Coinbase users earn interest by lending digital assets—specifically, a stablecoin called USD Coin—to others. That’s how Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong described the SEC’s latest crypto crackdown. According to Coinbase, the Wall Street regulator has sent the leading crypto exchange a “Wells notice” regarding its upcoming lending product, Lend.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Examining the Pop Culture Legacy of the September 11 Attacks
item.description: Now, with villains once again razing cities in films like Batman v Superman, it appears that 9/11 imagery has become “subtext instead of text,” Vox wrote. Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later. How long will it be before a director pitches a pandemic film?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 9
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: In the Afghan countryside, the endless killing of civilians turned women against the occupiers who claimed to be helping them.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Your employees' mental health care starts with your own
item.description: “Take time off,” Hartless said.  With burnout on the rise, Hartless said it’s essential that companies give workers the ability to create boundaries. Make room beyond Zoom According to July’s Mental Health Index: US Worker Edition, which synthesized random survey results of 500 workers, the risk of generalized anxiety among US workers has risen 94% since July and 98% since the beginning of the pandemic. To combat that sense of unrelenting work, she said it’s important to let workers know that they can switch their cameras off during video calls, and take time off to tend to their own mental health. At Mitel, the company created a “Wellness Village,” crammed with employee resources, such as webinars where workers can vent about their struggles during the pandemic.  Hartless said her company has implored its leaders to “open the door” by addressing mental health; in one example, she recalled an executive who talked about his long battle with mental health for a group of employees. HR’s function as an emotional sounding board for employees has only intensified during the pandemic, despite the fact that HR professionals are also suffering.
item.author: Sam Blum

item.title: The Death and Life of NYC’s Financial District
item.description: In the years after the attacks, many banks left the neighborhood, primarily for Midtown. Watch any episode of Billions or Succession and you’re bound to see multiple tracking shots of lower Manhattan, showcasing the district as a global hub for finance. – NF  Looking ahead... The neighborhood’s residential population has more than doubled since 2000, according to a WSJ analysis. Plus, more people made FiDi their actual home.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 8
item.description: Women accounted for a record 59.5% of college students at the end of the 2020–2021 school year, while men made up just 40.5%. (The Guardian)  Read: The disastrous voyage of Satoshi, the world’s first cryptocurrency cruise ship.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ford Poaches Senior Executive, Doug Field, from Apple's Car Project
item.description: And now for some news Apple definitely won’t send any invites over: Ford has poached the executive who led Apple’s secretive car project to become its own “chief advanced technology and embedded systems officer.” — NF
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New Apple iPhones to be Announced Next Week
item.description: Apple could also use the event to announce new AirPods, Apple Watches, and streaming content or devices for Apple TV+. Yesterday, the company sent out invites for its annual (and still virtual) launch event where it’ll announce new products. – JW
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Dealmaking, from M&A to IPOs, on Track to Break Records in 2021
item.description: IPOs2021 has been the busiest year for IPOs since 2000, according to Axios. 279 companies have IPO’d in the US this year, easily beating last year’s total of 218. A most excellent question, considering corporate deals of all kinds, from takeovers to IPOs, are happening at a record-setting pace this year. – NF because it’s hard to get much work done in Mykonos, August was its typical slow self for dealmaking.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ford Poaches Senior Executive, Doug Field, from Apple's Car Project
item.description: And now for some news Apple definitely won’t send any invites about: Ford has poached the executive who reportedly led Apple’s secretive car project to become its own “chief advanced technology and embedded systems officer.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Batteries Are a Solid Opportunity for EVs
item.description: Ford and BMW have partnered with another solid-state battery startup, Solid Power.  Why it matters: EV batteries are a key arena as automakers compete to make cheaper and more durable electric and hybrid vehicles. Besides Toyota, other automakers have also made bids on advanced battery tech: Volkswagen invested in the Bill Gates-backed battery startup QuantumScape.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: New Apple iPhones to be Announced Next Week
item.description: Apple could also use the event to announce new AirPods, Apple Watches, and streaming content or devices for Apple TV+. Yesterday, the company sent out invites for its annual (and still virtual) launch event where it’ll announce new products.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Toyota Spends $13.6 Billion to Develop Electric Vehicle Battery Technology
item.description: Ford and BMW have partnered with another solid-state battery startup, Solid Power.  Why it matters: EV batteries are a key arena as automakers compete to make cheaper and more durable electric and hybrid vehicles. Besides Toyota, other automakers have also made bids on advanced battery tech: Volkswagen invested in the Bill Gates-backed battery startup QuantumScape.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Dealmaking, from M&A to IPOs, on Track to Break Records in 2021
item.description: IPOs2021 has been the busiest year for IPOs since 2000, according to Axios. 279 companies have IPO’d in the US this year, easily beating last year’s total of 218. But get ready for a deluge of announcements once bankers head back to their monitors this fall, including potential IPOs from Chobani, Discord, Reddit, Instacart, and Rivian. because it’s hard to get much work done in Santorini, August was its typical slow self for dealmaking. The dealmaking surge is one the main reasons Goldman is the best performing stock in the Dow this year, up 56%.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Death and Life of NYC’s Financial District
item.description: The backstory: On the eve of 9/11, the Financial District (FiDi), was a finance hub.  In the years since, many banks left the neighborhood, primarily for Midtown. the Covid-19 pandemic has presented fresh challenges for FiDi, with a major downturn in the number of commuters and tourists hurting local businesses. The neighborhood’s residential population has more than doubled since 2000, according to a WSJ analysis.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Study Shows Automated Résumé Scanner Mistakenly Rejects Millions of Viable Job Candidates
item.description: Some of those keywords might not seem obvious. While there are 10 million job openings in the US that employers desperately want to fill, automated hiring systems are excluding viable candidates.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 7
item.description: (Incunabula) This thread explains.  Read: How did ham and cheese lead to hardcover books? “It may have been the financial promotion with the single biggest audience reach in history,” Randell said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Longer Waits, Safer Planes: How 9/11 Changed Air Travel
item.description: After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US revamped its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Airlines took a hit: Airline revenue for domestic US flights fell by $10 billion/year from 2001–2006. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Weibo, China’s version of Twitter, Suspends 21+ K-Pop Fan Accounts
item.description: Later that day, Weibo said it would ban a number of other celebrity accounts in an effort to “purify” its platform. When Americans were all winding down from their second Saturday, Weibo—China’s version of Twitter—suspended at least 21 fan accounts for K-pop bands like BTS and Blackpink. – MM
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: El Salvador’s Grand Bitcoin Experiment
item.description: Welcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender. Bukele also thinks that, by being an early adopter, the country could become a destination for foreign investment in bitcoin mining.  One-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad. Today, the Central American nation will become the first sovereign state to make bitcoin “legal tender,” meaning it’s now an official currency alongside the US dollar.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Longer Waits, Safer Planes: How 9/11 Changed Air Travel
item.description: After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US revamped its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Airlines struggled to recover: Airline revenue for domestic US flights fell by $10 billion/year from 2001–2006. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: El Salvador’s Grand Bitcoin Experiment
item.description: Welcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender.  Like all experiments, this one could backfireDespite all the buzz around digital currencies, bitcoin hasn’t been used as one at scale before.  And because bitcoin by definition skirts traditional financial institutions that promote stability, the International Monetary Fund is concerned that El Salvador’s adoption of the crypto could create serious risks for the country’s economy.  One-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 7
item.description: (Incunabula) This thread explains.  Read: How did ham and cheese lead to hardcover books? “It may have been the financial promotion with the single biggest audience reach in history,” Randell said.

When Americans were all winding down from their second Saturday, Weibo—China’s version of Twitter—suspended at least 21 fan accounts for K-pop bands like BTS and Blackpink. – MM

item.title: Study Shows Automated Résumé Scanner Mistakenly Rejects Millions of Viable Job Candidates
item.description: But some of those keywords might not seem obvious. While there are 10 million job openings in the US that employers desperately want to fill, the flawed automated hiring systems are excluding viable candidates.

item.title: The Week Ahead: September 6
item.description: 9/11 anniversary: As we mentioned earlier, Saturday will mark 20 years since the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The FDA will decide by Thursday whether Juul’s devices and nicotine pods can stay on the market.
item.author: Neal Freyman
